ms86.name: Center of Mass and Momentum Conservation (Collision)

questions.body: A rod length AB is moving with ends remaining in contact with frictionless wall and floor. If at the instant shown, the velocity of end B is 3 ms-1 towards negative x-direction, then magnitude of velocity of end A will be

explanation.en:
From geometry, it is clear that x=lcos⁡θ and y=lsin⁡θ

∴ vx=dxdv=-lsin⁡θdθdt  and vy=dydt=lcos⁡θdθdt




∴ vyvx=-cot⁡θ  or  vy=-vxcot⁡θ

Since, vx=-3 ms-1, hence

vy=--3cot⁡60°=3×13=3 ms-1

questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.body: In a modified Young's double slit experiment, a monochromatic uniform and parallel beam of light of wavelength 6000 Å and intensity 10πwm-2 is incident normally on two circular apertures A and B of radii 0.001m and 0.002m respectively. A perfectly transparent film of thickness 2000 Å and refractive index 1.5 for the wavelength of 6000 Å is placed in front of aperture A as shown in figure. Calculate the power (in microwatt) received at the focal spot F of the lens. The lens is symmetrically placed with respect to the apertures. Assume that 10% of the power received by each aperture goes in the original direction and is brought to the focal length.

explanation.en:
The power transmitted through A

PA=10% of10λ×π0.0012

=10100×10λ×π×10-6=10-6watt

The power transmitted through 'B' is

PB=10% of10λ×π0.0022

=10100×10π×π×4×10-6=4×10-6 watt

Let ϕ be the phse difference t = introduced by film

ϕ=2πλx=2πλ×μ-1t=2π6000×10-10×0.5×2000×10-10

ϕ=π3 redian .

The power received at F

P=PA+PB+2PAPBcos⁡ϕ

=10-6+4×10-6+210-6×4×10-6×12

=5×10-6+2×10-6=7×10-6=7μW

P=7μW

questions.subject: Physics

questions.body: In a motor, a rotor is fitted with the armature that has current of 10 A. The rotor rotates with angular speed of 3 rad/s. Magnetic field of magnitude 2 T varies in direction in such a way that it is always perpendicular to the loop area. If the rotor coil has N number of turns and area of each loop is 0.45 m2 then find the value N. Given that motor consumes 2106 W power and there are no losses.

explanation.en:
Torque  τ = M → × B →

= NI A → × B → = NI AB

= N × 1 0 × 0.45 × 2 = 9 N

Power = Torque × angular speed

2 1 0 6 = τ × ω

2 1 0 6 = 9 N × 3

N = 7 8

questions.subject: Physics

questions.body:
An ideal monatomic gas undergoes different types of processes which are described in column-I match the corresponding effects in column-II. The letters have usual meaning.
 
  Column-I   Column-II
A P=2V2 P If volume increases then temperature will also increase
B PV2= constant Q If volume increases then temperature will also decrease
C C=Cv+2R R For expansion, heat will have to be supplied to the gas
D C=Cv-2R S If temperature increases then work done by gas in positive

answers.body: <math><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>

<math><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math>

<math><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math>

<math><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi></math>

body.en: <math><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math>

explanation.en:
A. If  P=2V2 , from ideal gas equation we get  2V3=nRT

        ∴  with increase in volume

       i. Temperature increases implies  dU=+ve

       ii. dw=+ve

       hence  dQ=dU+dw=+ve

       B. If  PV2=  constant, constant, from ideal gas equation we get  VT = k  (constant)

       Hence with increase in volume, temperature decreases

       Now  dQ = dU + PdV = nCvdT –PKT2 dT   [∵dV = –KT2 dT]

        = nCV dT –PVT dT = n(Cv–R)dT

∴  with increase in temperature  dT = +ve  and since  CV >R  for monoatomic gas. Hence  dQ = +ve  as temperature is increased

C.  dQ = nC dT = nCv dT + PdV

⇒ n(Cv + 2R) dT = nCv dT + PdV

∴ 2nRdT = PdV 

∴dVdT = +ve

Hence with increase in temperature volume increase and vice versa

∴ dQ = dU + dw = +ve

D.  dQ = nC dT = nCv dT = PdV

Or  n (Cv–2R)dT = nCvdT + PdV

Or  –2nRdT = PdV 

∴dVdT = –ve

∴  with increase in volume temperature decreases. Also  dQ = n(Cv–2R) dT

with increase in temperature  dT = + ve  but  Cv < 2R  for monoatomic gas. Therefore  dQ = –ve  with increase in temperature.

questions.subject: Physics

questions.body:
Statement-1: A wire of uniform cross section and uniform resitivity is connected across an ideal cell. Now the length of the wire is doubled keeping volume of wire constant. The drift velocity of electrons after stretching the wire becomes one fourth of what it was before stretching the wire.

Statement-2: If a wire (of uniform resitivity and uniform cross-section) of length ℓ o   is stretched to length n ℓ o , then its resistance becomes n2 times of what it was before stretching the wire (the volume of wire is kept constant in stretching process). Further at constant potential difference, current is inversely proportional to resistance. Finally drift velocity of free electron is directly proportional to current and inversely proportional to cross section area of current carrying wire.

answers.body: Statement-1 is True, Statement-2 is False.
Statement – 1 is True, Statement -2 is True, Statement-2 is Not a correct explanation for Statement-1.
Statement – 1 is True, Statement -2 is True; Statement-2 is a correct explanation for statement-1.
Statement-1 is False, Statement-2 is True.

body.en: Statement-1 is False, Statement-2 is True.

explanation.en:
As the length of wire is doubled, the cross-section area of wire becomes half. Therefore resistance of wire becomes four times and current becomes 1 4 th of the initial value.
also v d = I neA
Since current becomes one fourth and cross-section area of wire becomes half, therefore from above equation the drift velocity of electron becomes half. Hence statement I is false.

questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.body: A line with positive direction cosines passes through the point P(2, -1, 2) and makes equal angles with the coordinate axes. The line meets the plane 2x + y + z = 9 at point Q. If the length of the line segment PQ is <math><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi></math> , then value of <math><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></math> is

explanation.en:
l=m=n=13 

2x+y+z=9

∴ equations of line are x-213=y+113=z-213

x-2=y+1=z-2=r

Q=r+2, r-1, r+2

∵ Q Lies on the plane 2x+y+z=9

2r+2+r-1+r+2=9

⇒4r+5=9⇒r=1

∴Q3, 0, 3

∴PQ=1+1+1=3

questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.body: Find the equation of the right bisector of the line segment joining the points (3, 4) and (–1, 2).

explanation.en:
Slope of the line joining the points A(–1, 2) and B(3, 4)

= 4 - 2 3 + 1 = 2 4 = 1 2

​

Right bisector PQ is perpendicular to AB

∴Slope of PQ = – 2

middle point of AB is - 1 + 3 2 2 + 4 2 i.e 1 3

Right bisector passes through M(1, 3)

Equation of right bisector PQ is y – 3 = –2

( x – 1) = –2x + 2

⇒  2x + y – 3 – 2 = 0   ⇒ 2x + y – 5 = 0

questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.body:
Match the entries of Column - I with one or more than one entries of Column - II.
 
Column – I Column – II
(A) The minimum value of x2+2x+4x+2,  x∈R is (P) 0
(B) If sin⁡x=cos⁡y , then the possible values of 1πx±y-π2 are (Q) 1
(C) If sin⁡nπ+x=sin⁡x , then a value of n can be (R) 2
(D) Let a=log3⁡log3⁡2 . An integer k, satisfying 1<2-k+3-a<2 , must be less than (S) 3

explanation.en:
A Let y=x2+2x+4x+2

⇒    x2+2-yx+4-2y=0

⇒    x2+2-yx+4-2y=0 , which is a quadratic in x having non-negative real roots.

∴     disc. ≥0

⇒    2-y2-44-2y≥0,

⇒    y2+4y-12≥0⇒  y2+4y+4≥16

⇒    y+2≥4  ⇒    y+2≤-4 or y+2≥4

But y>0 , therefore, y≥2.

Hence, min⁡y=2.

Note that x=0 givens y=2.

B sin⁡x=cos⁡y

⇒   cos⁡π2-x=cos⁡y

⇒  π2-x=2nπ±y, n∈I

C sin⁡nπ+x=sin⁡x

⇒   -1nsin⁡x=sin⁡x

⇒   n is an even integer.

D First we compute 3-a

Now 3-a=3-log3⁡log3⁡2

=3log3⁡log3⁡2-1=log3⁡2-1=1log3⁡2-log2⁡3

∴    2-k+3-a=2-k2log2⁡3 =2-k×3

Hence, 1<2-k+3-a<2  ⇒   1<3×2-k<2

⇒   13<12k<23  ⇒   3>2k>32

∴    k lies between 0 and 2.

questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.body:
Statement - 1 : Sum of the series 13 - 23 + 33 - 43 + ... + 113 = 378.
Statement - 2 : For any odd integer n ≥ 1 , n 3 - n - 1 3 + ... + - 1 n - 1 1 3 = 1 4 2 n - 1 n + 1 2

answers.body: Statement 1 is true and statement 2 is false.
Both the statements are true and statement 2 is the correct explanation of statement 1.
Both the statements are true but statement 2 is not the correct explanation of statement 1.
Statement 1 is false and statement 2 is true.

body.en: Statement 1 is false and statement 2 is true.

explanation.en:
For odd integer n, we have
  S n = n 3 - n - 1 3 + ... + - 1 n - 1 1 3

      = 1 3 - 2 3 + 3 3 - 4 3 + ... + n 3

  = 1 3 + 2 3 + 3 3 + ... + n - 1 3 + n 3 - 2 2 3 + 4 3 + 6 3 + ... + n - 1 3
       = n 2 n + 1 2 4 - 2 × 2 3 1 3 + 2 3 + ... + n - 1 2 3

        = n 2 n + 1 2 4 - 2 4 n - 1 2 2 n - 1 2 + 1 2 4


         = n 2 n + 1 2 4 - n - 1 2 n + 1 2 4

         = n + 1 2 4 n 2 - n - 1 2

        = 1 4 2 n - 1 n + 1 2

Now, putting n = 11 in above formula, S11 = 756. Hence statement 1 is false and statement 2 is correct.

questions.body: If  a, b, c <math> <mrow> <mo>∈</mo> <mi></mi><mi></mi><mi></mi><mi></mi><mi></mi><mi></mi><mi></mi><mi></mi><mi>R</mi><mo>⁡</mo> <mi>,</mi><mo>⁡</mo> <mi>a</mi> <mo>≠</mo> <mn>0 </mn> </mrow> </math> and the quadratic equation ax<sup>2</sup> + bx + c = 0 has no real roots, then (a + b + c ) c > 0.

explanation.en:
Since, f⁡ x = a x 2 + b x + c = 0  has no real roots, either f⁡ x > 0 ,⁡  ∀ x ∈ R⁡  or  ⁡ f⁡ x < 0 ,⁡  ∀ x ∈ R⁡ . In the former case,we have f (1) > 0 & f (0) > 0, which yields a + b + c > 0 & c < 0, so that (a + b + c) c > 0, on the other hand if f (x) < 0, both f (1) and f (0) are less than zero, giving a + b + c < 0 and c < 0, so that again (a + b + c) c > 0.
(OR)
And the graph for that :


So f (0) f ( 1) > 0.
⇒   (a + b + c) c > 0.

       Difference  =35-3 ≃4

questions.body:
Column I   Column II  
S.No Benzil-Benzilic acid rearrangement    Attack of O ⊖ H group Migrating group
a p At C-1 p-MeO-C6H4-
    q At C-2 Ph-
b r At C-1 p-MeO-C6H4-
    s At C-2 m-MeO-C6H4-
c t At C-1 p-Et-C6H4-
    u At C-2 p-Me-C6H4-
d v At C-1 p-i-Pr-C6H4-
    w At C-2 p-Et-C6H4-

explanation.en:
In Benzil-Benzilic acid rearrangment reaction O ⊖ H  reacts at the more reactive (C = O) group attached to benzene ring containing EWG; and the same group is migrated.

C 2 = O  is more reactive than C 1 = O  (+R and – effect of OMe) and Ph migrates.

C 2 = O  is more reactive (Only -I effect of OMe group at meta) than C 1 = O  (+R and –I effect of OMe group at para ), so (m-MeO-C6H4-) group migrates.

C 1 = O  is more reactive less e ¯ - donating Et group, two H.C. structure than C 2 = O   more e ¯ - donating Me group, three H.C. structure . So (p-Et-C6H4) group migrates.

C 1 = O  more reactive less e ¯ - donating (i-Pr) group, one H.C. structure  than C 2 = O   more e ¯ - donating (Et) group, two H.C. structures . So (p-i-Pr-C6H4-) group migrates.

(a) If the lines x + 2ay + a = 0, x + 3by + b = 0, x + 4cy + c = 0, where a, b, c ∈   R concurrent, then a, b, c are in (p) A.P.
(b) The points with coordinates (2a, 3a), (3b, 2b) (c, c) where a, b, c ∈  R are collinear, then a, b, c are in (q) G.P.
(c) If lines ax + 2y + 1 = 0, bx + 3y + 1 = 0 and cx + 4y + 1 = 0 where a, b, c ∈  R passes through the same point, then a, b, c are in (r)
 		 H.P.
(d) Let a, b, c be distinct non-negative real numbers. If the lines ax + ay + c = 0, x + 1 = 0, cx + cy + b = 0 pass through the same point then a, c, b are in (s) neither A.P. nor G.P. nor H.P.

explanation.en:
a-r, b-s, c-p, d-q

(a) 1 2 a a 1 3 b b 1 4 c c = 0

= - bc - 2 a c - b + a 4 c - 3 b

= - bc + 2 ac - ab

⇒    2 b = 1 a + 1 c

(b) 2 a 3 a 1 3 b 2 b 1 c c 1 = 0 = bc + ac - 5 ab = 0

(c) a 2 1 b 3 1 c 4 1 = 0

= 4 b - 3 c - 4 a + 2 c + 3 a - 2 b

= 2 b - a - c   ⇒   a + c = 2 b

(d) a a c c c b 1 0 1 = 0 = ab - c 2 + 0

⇒    c 2 = ab

questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.body:
Statement-1: A wire of uniform cross section and uniform resitivity is connected across an ideal cell. Now the length of the wire is doubled keeping volume of wire constant. The drift velocity of electrons after stretching the wire becomes one fourth of what it was before stretching the wire.

Statement-2: If a wire (of uniform resitivity and uniform cross-section) of length ℓ o   is stretched to length n ℓ o , then its resistance becomes n2 times of what it was before stretching the wire (the volume of wire is kept constant in stretching process). Further at constant potential difference, current is inversely proportional to resistance. Finally drift velocity of free electron is directly proportional to current and inversely proportional to cross section area of current carrying wire.

answers.body: Statement-1 is True, Statement-2 is False.
Statement – 1 is True, Statement -2 is True, Statement-2 is Not a correct explanation for Statement-1.
Statement – 1 is True, Statement -2 is True; Statement-2 is a correct explanation for statement-1.
Statement-1 is False, Statement-2 is True.

body.en: Statement-1 is False, Statement-2 is True.

explanation.en:
As the length of wire is doubled, the cross-section area of wire becomes half. Therefore resistance of wire becomes four times and current becomes 1 4 th of the initial value.
also v d = I neA
Since current becomes one fourth and cross-section area of wire becomes half, therefore from above equation the drift velocity of electron becomes half. Hence statement I is false.

questions.subject: Physics

questions.body: Fluorine is most electronegative atom, through BF<sub>3</sub> is the strongest Lewis acid amongst BX<sub>3</sub>.

explanation.en:
Fluorine is most electronegative atom; therefore it has the highest electron withdrawing power. On the basis of electro negativity, boron in BF3 should have been the most electron deficient and should have attracted a Lewis base to the most. BF3 should have been the strongest Lewis  acid .



Electron withdrawing  power decreases from F to I, electron deficiency should have been maximum at B in BF3 and it should have acted as strongest Lewis acid amongst the four BX3.

The real situation is somewhat different and BF3 is the weakest Lewis acid. This contradiction is explained on the basis of compensation of electron deficiency at central  boron by back bonding from the halogen atom boned to it . Just as now we have discussed, the extent of back bonding is maximum with fluorine atom, and therefore electron deficiency by means of back bonding overcomes the effect of electron - withdrawal by electro negativity and B in the BF3 is the least deficient, and thus the weakest Lewis acid
